abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Woman and Child
            Development Project for India were as follows: the outcome
            was moderately satisfactory, risk to development outcome
            moderate, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project:
            the Bank and the government should agree on the timing of
            government approval of a Bank-assisted project; at
            negotiations, the Bank and Government should discuss and
            agree on the stability or longevity of project management
            staff to stem the adverse effects of the high staff turnover
            rates; lessons learned from previous projects, both positive
            and negative, should be rigorously analyzed and applied to
            the subsequent project design, and a new initiative should
            be pilot tested on a small scale; the quality at entry of
            the project profoundly affected efficiency of project
            implementation; extension of the closing date can be an
            effective instrument for expediting project implementation;
            in addition to input and process indicators, more output
            indicators should be used; the weak financial management and
            disbursement documentation were important causes of project
            implementation delays; institutional and organizational
            issues need more attention in national schemes; and a
            specific investment project is not an optimal tool for
            meeting the varied needs and capacities of different states
            in a large federated nation as India.
